Package servlets

Class GraphRefresh

  • java.lang.Object
    • servlets.GraphRefresh
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Servlet
    public class GraphRefresh
extends java.lang.Object
implements Servlet
    GraphRefresh servlet provides real-time graph visualization by serving updated HTML with current topic values. This servlet generates fresh graph visualizations that reflect the current state of all topics and agents in the computational graph system.

    The servlet is designed to be called periodically or on-demand to provide up-to-date visualizations of the computational graph. It integrates with the HtmlGraphWriter to generate SVG or Canvas-based graph representations that include current topic values and agent relationships.

    Supported HTTP Methods

    • GET - Retrieve current graph visualization with live topic values

    Request Format

    Simple GET request with no required parameters: 

    
 GET /graph HTTP/1.1
 Host: localhost:8080

    Response Format

    Returns HTML content with embedded graph visualization:

    • Success (200 OK) - Complete HTML page with SVG/Canvas graph visualization
    • Error (200 OK) - HTML error page with error message and navigation

    The HTML response includes:

    • Interactive graph visualization (SVG or Canvas)
    • Current topic values displayed on nodes
    • Agent relationships and data flow arrows
    • Styling and layout for optimal visualization

    Graph Visualization Features

    The generated graph visualization includes:

    • Topic Nodes - Circular nodes showing topic names and current values
    • Agent Nodes - Rectangular nodes representing computational agents
    • Data Flow Arrows - Directed edges showing message flow between topics and agents
    • Real-time Values - Current topic values are fetched and displayed
    • Interactive Elements - Clickable nodes and hover effects

    Integration with System Components

    • HtmlGraphWriter - Primary component for generating graph HTML
    • TopicManagerSingleton - Source of current topic values and relationships
    • Agent System - Provides agent information and computational graph structure

    Use Cases

    • Real-time monitoring of computational graph state
    • Debugging agent interactions and message flow
    • Educational visualization of graph-based computations
    • System status monitoring and health checks

    Performance Considerations

    The servlet generates fresh HTML on each request, which provides real-time accuracy but may have performance implications for large graphs. The visualization is optimized for typical graph sizes and includes efficient rendering strategies.

    Since:
    1.0
    See Also:
    HtmlGraphWriter.getGraphHTML(), TopicManagerSingleton, Servlet.handle(RequestInfo, OutputStream)

    • Method Detail

      • handle

        public void handle​(RequestParser.RequestInfo ri,
                   java.io.OutputStream toClient)
            throws java.io.IOException
        Handles HTTP GET requests to generate and serve real-time graph visualizations. This method creates a fresh HTML representation of the current computational graph state, including all topics, agents, and their current values.

        The method performs the following operations:

        1. Invokes HtmlGraphWriter to generate current graph HTML
        2. Retrieves real-time topic values from the system
        3. Constructs complete HTML response with proper headers
        4. Sends the visualization to the client

        The generated HTML includes:

        • SVG or Canvas-based graph visualization
        • Topic nodes with current values
        • Agent nodes showing computational components
        • Directed edges representing data flow
        • Interactive styling and layout

        Error Handling

        If graph generation fails, the method returns an HTML error page with the error message and navigation options. All exceptions are caught and logged for debugging purposes.

        Specified by:
        handle in interface Servlet
        Parameters:
        ri - the RequestInfo containing the HTTP request data (no parameters required)
        toClient - the OutputStream to write the HTML response to
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if there are errors writing to the output stream
        See Also:
        HtmlGraphWriter.getGraphHTML(), sendHtmlResponse(OutputStream, String), sendErrorResponse(OutputStream, String)

      • close

        public void close()
           throws java.io.IOException
        Description copied from interface: Servlet
        Releases any resources held by this servlet and performs cleanup operations.

        This method is called during server shutdown or when the servlet is being unregistered from the HTTP server. Implementations should:

        • Close any open files, database connections, or network resources
        • Stop any background threads or scheduled tasks
        • Release any cached data or temporary resources
        • Perform any necessary state persistence

        For stateless servlets that don't hold external resources, this method may be a no-op but should still be implemented for consistency.

        This method should be idempotent - calling it multiple times should not cause errors or unexpected behavior. It should also complete quickly to avoid delaying server shutdown.

        Resource Cleanup Example

        
 public void close() throws IOException {
     // Close database connections
     if (dataSource != null) {
         try {
             dataSource.close();
         } catch (SQLException e) {
             // Log error but don't throw - cleanup should continue
             System.err.println("Error closing database: " + e.getMessage());
         }
     }
     
     // Stop background tasks
     if (scheduledExecutor != null) {
         scheduledExecutor.shutdown();
         try {
             if (!scheduledExecutor.awaitTermination(5, TimeUnit.SECONDS)) {
                 scheduledExecutor.shutdownNow();
             }
         } catch (InterruptedException e) {
             scheduledExecutor.shutdownNow();
             Thread.currentThread().interrupt();
         }
     }
     
     // Clear caches
     if (cache != null) {
         cache.clear();
     }
     
     // Clear references
     dataSource = null;
     scheduledExecutor = null;
     cache = null;
 }

        Cleanup Best Practices

        • Don't throw exceptions from close() - log errors instead
        • Use try-catch blocks around individual cleanup operations
        • Set object references to null after cleanup
        • Use timeouts for operations that might hang
        • Consider using try-with-resources for automatic cleanup
        Specified by:
        close in interface Servlet
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if an I/O error occurs during resource cleanup. Implementations should minimize the likelihood of this by handling individual cleanup failures gracefully.
        See Also:
        Servlet.handle(RequestInfo, OutputStream)
